column4: Hi - I am attempting to figure out what the term "multiplexer" means in the following context: "If you have access to an SSH server where you can install and run  Irssi, it is also recommended to install screen, a terminal multiplexer."
you have more then 1 terminal at a time, you switch btween them via key combox.
you could think of your tv as a 'video multiplexer' :) it can change channels..
screen is WORTH learning to use if you are going to be using ssh/terminal a lot
okay
you ssh in, run screen, then run irssi in screen.. you dont need to run a 2nd ssh session then
unless you WANT to run it locally...
so you dont need to run a second ssh session some where else...
thats the whold point of screen... sssh in once.. have dozen+ shells going if you want..
your use of the term 'just a '   is belittling :)
gcc --version  ?
most apps have a --version option :)
some odd ones  dont.. but they are rare. :)
yep. It pays to learn the fundamentals.. and you get amazed at how well thoguht out/logical linux can be. :) well parts of it at least.
think of 'legos and layers' Linux is lots of little blocks. building up layers of the OS. It pays to learn at least the basics of the blocks.
I buy lots of linux books from the clearance section of the book store.. keep them in the 'reading room'  :) and read them for about 5 min every morning,.,.
how do you manage to remember all that stuff?
my main concern is with biology
you rember what you use.. and  if i stumble upon somthing i need to learn/use.. i 'rember' that i saw it in some book.. and i go back to it.
for example. I dont Use scp every day.. but i rember the basics of what i read   and the core idea that 'scp' is supposed to work like 'cp' only with  user@server type addresses also. :)
it might also need 'sun java' not the other java.
run it from terminal. look for error messatges
